text:
Very strong Amber taste. A bit too strong for me, but it has a nice dark color and a sweet bottle. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Very nice and smooth beer, very deep and nice amber colour and strong sweet aroma, beer that you would definitely drink more of!

Bomber from Beer Gonzo cons 2017-06-14 Uddingston 
AR: old buttery, tropical fruity, grape fruit
AP: ruby, stouty cream beige lid
F: bitter, tropical fruity, citrusy, pine, bitter dark chocolate

Brought back from San Francisco by my son - thanks! Hazy, tea-colored pour, bone colored head, nice lacing. Aroma has a very solid sweetness to it with some juicy fruit gum candy-like notes. Solid flavor, some caramel sweetness, hints of cherry fruitiness. light underlying citrus bitterness, Thick, creamy mouthfeel. Solid amber ale, as expected from Alesmith.

Bottle. Dark clear red with a resilient beige head. Lacing is fairly heavy. Surprisingly hoppy aroma with caramel, chocolate, toast, earth and flowers. Moderately sweet, toasty and nicely bitter. Smooth and medium bodied with a little dryness. Very nice amber.

65cl Bottle @ LaBIRRAtorium, Madrid, Spain.
Dark reddish brown colour with a thick white head.
Aroma is hops, pine, dark fruits, citrus, malt, toffee.
Taste is hops, resin, malt, molasses.
Medium to full body, average carbonation.

Es una cerveza completamente deliciosa, con un cuerpo ligero pero de sabores bien asentados, con una fluidez interesante para el paladar, con un aroma suave algo tropical, el color es un rojo oxido lo que le da una fuerza al nombre de la cerveza. simplemente genial. para mi lista de las 100 favoritas ‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§‚ù§

clear mahogany colour, huge, dense creamy yellowish-beige-ish head; aroma of pine resin, orange zest oils, biscuity and rye bread notes; taste is the same with some roasted and dried fruity notes; good one, though not among the best AleSmith beers
Muy interesante red/amber. De aroma caramelizado, a tofe y frescor de l√∫pulo. Un pel√≠n m√°s maltosa y ser√≠a una joya, pero muy al nivel de la f√°brica...

22floz bottle, no freshness, paid $7, poured into an imperial nonic glass. This beer looks really good: deep, dark amber (reddish-brown). Smells good: a deciduous forest with undertones of citrus and caramel. Taste and mouthfeel is pretty good: like burnt biscuits spritz with grapefruit. Basically this is a red IPA, not really balanced, but maybe not supposed to be. It¬ís good, but I¬íd have liked for there to be a greater malt presence.

Bottle. Clear crimson color, rocky white head. Fruity aroma, dark fruit plums, low piney notes, hops, Smooth flavor. Tastes like it smells. Some fruit, pine, resin. Grainy malt, slight sweetness. Well balanced.
2/14 Reminded me of Oggis Hop Whompus, nough said. ...Well nearly enough..
A lot of caramel, slight roasted taste, some chocolate. Maybe a bit to much hops for me.

22 ounce bottle. Pours a deep red, copper topped by a large frothy beige head. Nice clinging lace. Rich caramel malt nose. First sip brings suggestions of bittersweet toasted malt. Burnt sugar and bitter chocolate are noticeable as well. Floral hops lead to bitter spiciness in the finish. Full bodied and complex. Delicious.
Bottle on 2/24. I have had a few times before. Pours dark red. Aroma of caramel. Medium bitterness , caramelly. Tasty.
Bottle: pours dark brown with a thin tan head, malty and sweet aroma, taste is toffee flavored, some coffee-like bitterness with a very dry finish

Great balanced and vivid taste with just a right amount of red berries to give it a refreshing twist. Huge, malty backbone.

The aroma is hoppy, citrus and some caramel. Pours dark amber with big beige head mostly lasting and excellent lacing. The taste is bitter. The body is medium, the texture creamy, the carbonation lively and the finish bitter. Very Good !

Pours a three fingered head that lingers and leaves a heavy lacing. Clear, dark Ruby. Very resinous, with burnt brown sugar, some caramel. mild to moderate sweet with mild to moderate bitterness. Full bodied, round mouthfeel. candy sugar. long, smooth finish with continuous resin hops, brown sugar notes. A good amber

Pours a deep ruby with a medium tan head...foamy lacing...excellent retentionm Aroma has notes of dark fruit, caramel, nougat, resinous hops. Flavor is more earthy resinous/bitter with subtle dark fruitiness...breadt. Mouthfeel is medium and lively with a dry earthy/bitter/faintly metallic finish.

Pours murky mahogany with two-finger sustained, almond head with large expansive bubbles. Malt outcompetes hops in aroma and taste leading to a smooth finish with modest but lingering bitterness. Forgot to open on V-day!
light malty aroma. red in color with really nice long lasting head. taste is of light roasted barley and chocolate. smooth clean finish

Bottle, 10C. Deep clear red with an inch of light beige head that lasts quite well as laces well. Aroma of toffee and pine with overripe tropical fruit and citrus in the background. Smooth and medium to full bodied, carbonation is on the low side of medium. More bready than suggested by the aroma - indeed the malt side of things is broader and perhaps less sweet than suggested by the aroma. The pine, too, is not as prominent as expected an nestles in with bitter oranges, mild spices and floral notes. The end is just bitter enough to (nearly) choke off the sweetness and keep you interested. Good stuff and really outstanding for an amber ale.

Aroma of sweet malt and caramel with notes of toffee. Pours a reddish brown with a lasting tan head with good lacing. A great taste of caramel, toffee and sweet malt a medium body with a sweet malt finish.

Poured from a bottle. Medium brown color, medium frothy off white head. Pepper malt aroma. Medium body with a peppery malt flavor and a medium finish. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Good sized frothy light bege head of fine and dense bubbles with good carbonation. Sweet aroma with some toffee, roasted grains, light vegetal aromas and some spicy hops. Color is a deep crimson. More sweetness in the flavor with some cinnamon, dry roasted malts, molasses and currents. Palate has a hint of chalkiness. Light alcohol presence. Light lingering dry bitterness. A decent brew.
On tap at Hopping Pig, San Diego. Dark amber with a small head. Aroma of hops, caramel and light toasted malt. Similar taste. The body was medium as was the bitterness.

Bomber. Caramel malt aroma with notes of toasted and toffee malt with a little bit of floral and pine hop aroma. Pours dark amber colored with one finger of tan head that has excellent retention but little lacing. Starts with sweet caramel malt flavors with a bit of toasted malt and toffee. Finishes a bit dry but with good floral and slight pine resiny hop bitterness to balance out the sweet malt nicely. Well made amber.
Tap. Dark amber color with tan ring. Aroma is caramel and toffee, slight pine hops. Taste is toffee, caramel, bready, raisins and pines. Sirupy mouthfeel without being too intense. Amazing Amber.
On tap at the brewery. Pours a dark amber with small beige head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is resin and caramel. Medium body, caramel, bread, light resin finish, good.

My Bloody Valentine is exactly what I¬íll need for February, but it works for December loneliness also. This beer pours ruby red. There¬ís toasty caramel and chocolate. Flavors are similarly candy-like, balancing sweet and toasted biscuit. Very light hoppiness toward the end. For a West Coast Amber, this is extremely mellow.

Aroma:

Medium/heavy aroma of malts, caramel, fruit, chocolate, pine, roasted malts, hops, citrus and grapefruit.

Appearance:

Opaque ruby/brown beer with a slight/medium beige/brown head.

Taste/Palate:

Starts medium/heavy sweet with malts, caramel, fruit, chocolate and pine; ends slightly bitter and dry with roasted malts, hops, citrus and grapefruit.

Overall:

This beer is intense, complex and balanced. Great amount of hop flavours, with loads of pine and citrus. The added malts and roasted malts give the perfect balance to this. Great aroma and palate, plus an amazing appearance. What a beer, this is Amber Ale heaven.

From bottle at Camping Ratebeer ¬í15. Pours a bit hazy brown with a medium tan head. Aroma is quite fruity with some red fruits, tropical fruits and hops. Taste has some caramel, pine, tropical fruits, hops and a medium bitter finish. Medium body and carbo.

appearance: dark cola brown, purplish highlights, fizzy and scant beige head.  aroma: caramel and brown sugar--almost treacly--with some raisin, cherry, leather, and chocolate, some citrusy notes in the background, like candied orange peel.  taste: sweet caramel, brown sugar, and molasses, with an undertone of milk chocolate, cherry, vanilla, and a current of citrus and a hint of pine.  finish: slightly chewy, lingering sweetness, nice note of brown toast. notes: Probably the fullest, sweetest I¬íve had in the style. Not bad at all.

Bottle a brown colored beer with a white head aroma malts citrus fruits dried fruits yeast spicy nuts and hops flavor malts citrus fruits pineapple grapefruits spicy some dried fruits some caramel earthly notes and bitter hops
Bomber pour to cup. Sweet sappy smell. Dark brown amber. Rich malts, maple, caramel. Satisfying body. Bitter wheat flavor finish.

22oz bottle, Bought by my daughter for her husband, drank on 12th May 2016 by my son and I on my daughters patio in the Californian sunshine. Rustic red/brown with a thin head. No mention of Rye on the bottle,but I thought this had a Rye like aroma and taste. Fairly sweet from the off with dark/red berries in both the nose and flavours along with the malts, Rye or not.

Bottle at Appellation Wines tasting. Clear ruby body with a thin beige head. Faint lacing. Aroma of maple syrup, strawberry and caramel. Flavour of jammy dodgers, grass, red fruits and strawberry syrup. Medium body with an oily mouthfeel. Soft fizz. Sweet and complex.
From bottle. Pours cloudy brown. Aromas of burnt toffee, caramel, molasses. On the palate; burnt sugar, caramel, resin.
Bottle at Comely Bankers III. Nose is hoppy resin, sweet caramel. Taste is dryer than nose, resinous hops, dry toffee, red fruits, caramel. Nice.

Bottle thanks to Amanda. 
Appearance - deep amber brown when a decent head. 
Nose - stewed redcurrants. Honey and cereal. 
Taste - cake mixture and more tangy red fruit.
Palate - close to medium bodied with a tangy texture and a long dry tangy finish.
Overall - really interesting beer.
Dark red ale. Interesting front taste. Almost tastes like a chocolate orange. Somewhat like a porter. Kind of thick texture but smooth. Fluffy aftertaste. Strange mintiness

bottle @ Jungle Jims / Cincinnati OH --- bottled 12/01/15; Aroma of caramel malt and chocolate. Opaque dark mahogany brown color, rocky beige head that never drops below 2", big swaths of lace. Taste is crisp. clean malt that adds caramel and light chocolate in a medium carbonated swallow, followed by light hops that fade into more malt at the end. Won¬ít please hopheads, but a truly remarkable brew for malt lovers. Balanced, complex, delicious, light in the stomach, a real keeper.

Bomber dated 12.01.15 poured into pint mug. Has a dark mahogany color under a big frothy beige head that leaves lots of lacing. Aroma has caramel and bready malts, chocolate, and floral hops. Taste is sweet at first, with a long bitter finish. Body is medium with average carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. One of the best amber ales I¬íve tried. Next year this will be a no-brainer to try again if it¬ís again on sale the month after Valentine¬ís Day.

Bomber. Piny, grassy nose, caramel, chocolate. Pretty reddish-brown color, nice foamy had that goes to lace quickly. FLavor is mineral, resin, chocolate, caramel. Full body. Nice balance, very bitter finish. Nice drinking beer.

Bomber. Thanks to KL. Tropical fruity nose, full maltiness, citrus, pine, Light reddish/brown, and yes, a bit bloody. Balanced from the start, good resiny hoppiness emerges, pleasant lightly malty finish. Thin-medium body, tingly hops on tongue. Tastes more IPA-ish than amber. Very nice.

22oz bomber. Deep burgundy brown-black body. Big, fluffy, steady, beige head. Respectable deep classic NW hop tones, some pine, grapefruit. Heavy deep specialty malts, more chocolate and roast than most examples, but the amber malt still shines through as well. Pretty optimum Amber, really well done.
Pours a deep mahogany color. Taste is licorice, pine, brown sugar, and Styrofoam. Nice beer for sure.

Pencil shavings, dried leaves, caramel, pine needle, grapefruit aroma, fairly strong, but a little stale. Clear ruby brown, medium tan head, good retention and glass adherence. Grapefruit, dried leaves, cherries, subtle hints of caramel. Medium body, easy carbonation.
Bomber to a pint. Blood orange color with ample off white head and lacing. Caramel, biscuit, floral and tropical notes. Taste follows. This beer was born in 2014, may be a little past its prime?
Tap at Ginger Man, New York. Originally rated 20160212. Colour is clear reddish copper with small white head. Aromas and flavours: Caramel, dryness, fruits and malts.

Keg @ Busters. Slightly hazy reddish pour with a small head. Nose is balanced citrus fruits and malt character. Toasted town bread and carMel. Grapefruit and cantaloupe spread. Flavor is similar. Sweet with a lightly hot bitter finish. Chewy and substantial. A bit boozy. Solid.

On tap at Mohawk Bend in shaker pint glass. Appearance is cloudy, orange-red dark brown (like a cloudy dark cider), with 1-2 finger width fluffy off-white head with nice lacing. Aroma is piney, citrus, floral hop dominant over caramel and toasted malt. Taste is piney over floral hops over caramel malt backbone with late cherry/fruit burst. Palate is light bodied with thin texture, soft carbonation, nice pleasant piney bitter finish. Overall, I got more pine than floral (which is fine by me). Different look and hop/malt balance.

Tap at Busters. Just a really well put together beer. Not mind blowing on any particular dimension except balance, which is a work of art here. Dense murky dark amber pour with a dense clingy head. Caramel and floral hop nose. Full palate. Taste is mild spice, a nice little floral hop bite, and some caramel and grain sweetness. Yummy stuff.

Bomber. Reddish brown (duh... amber) pour, medium off-white head with decent retention and lace. Nose is caramel, biscuity malt, candied orange, raisins, dried leaves. Mouth is medium-full, mild malt sweetness, caramel, dried fruit, pleasantly bitter, yeah... tastes pretty much like it smells.

22 oz bottle obtained through Tavour. AleSmith My Bloody Valentine is a very reddish brown clearer brew with a thin head that has a slight pinkish cast. Nose is medium roasted malt, caramel and dark chocolate. Taste is more of the same. very solid malt forward with a touch of hops and good chocolate bitter on the finish. Very fun and awesome beer for valentine¬ís day.

Bomber. Rich caramelly nose with a hint of molasses. Dark reddish brown with a beautiful yellowish head and excellent lace. For an amber ale this has an awesome subtle hop finish. Dry yet interesting. Best and most interesting low ABV beer I¬íve had in some time.

22oz bomber size bottle acquired by blondredhead from Total Wine & Spirits in Roseville. Consumed in a Belgian snifter glass. Deep ruby red/amber colored ale with an off white head. Aroma is kind of like a subdued IPA...hoppy qualities are present right away. Taste has a malty influence with sweetness more prevalent than expected. Some chocolate and caramel characteristics. Hop comes back towards the end with some light bitterness and a piney resin. Mouthfeel mirrors a traditional IPA with a shorter finish. Overall, I¬ím enjoying this one more than anticipated. Alesmith has better options but as their seasonals go, I can definitely get behind this one. The band is terrible. The beer is really good.

Not as good as Alesmith's other seasonals but still pretty good. A nice bitterness for an amber. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

From a bomber. Pours a ruby red and makes a thin beige head. Not much lacing. Aroma is of spices and malt and a bit of cherry. Tastes very malty with a bit of coriander. Love this beer. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

light reddish brown under a dense crown of light beige foam. Pleasant malt aroma, prunes, candy, bread and toffee. On the other hand green pine cones, resins and orange peels. In the mouth a pleasant bitterness that cohabits with the sweetness of the malt. Notes of citrus peels, resins, pineapples and oranges in taste, lasting aftertaste quite remarkable. Soft and full bodied with a nice level of carbonation.

Poured from the bomber reddish brown with white head. Taste is a spicy, sweet malty brown ale, I like the 3-6¬ís alcohol content, but if you are going to advertise this to people feeling bad about themselves about being alone on a greeting card and teddy bear company created holiday make it 10-12% so they can really forget their troubles, otherwise pretty good.

659 ml bottle. Pours a clear red brown with moderate head. Aromas of candied fruit, brown sugar, sweet toasted malts and pine.
Flavors of same with candi sugar and more pine. Yummy.
Tap. Brownish red color. Very sharp aroma. Bitter to the end. Ok, but just ok.
Bomber. Poured reddish brown with white head. Caramel malts, distinctive pine baeed hops. Nicely done.

Draft at brew Santa Rosa. Deep crimson amber coloured pour with a lasting creamy light tan head. Aroma is perfumed citrus, light toasted grains, fresh pine, hints of caramel. Flavour is composed of rounded caramel , toffee, pine needle, hint of strawberry cake. Palate is full and sticky, rounded. Moderate carbonation.

How hadn¬ít I reviewed this yet? Poor form, clown. Welp, bomber. Hazy dark reddish brown color with a sticky off-white head. Big hop aroma, floral and citrusy, with toasty caramel notes backing it up. The flavor is quite nice, toasty with a bitter finish. Sweet caramel/cocoa, but mostly dry. Medium-bodied with a biting bitterness. Good.

22 oz. bottle. Pours a dark reddish pour with a thick, off white head. Aroma of pine and crystal malt. Flavor is mildly sweet with strong pine and resin. Flavor is balanced, malty with a strong piney hoppy presence. Full, creamy body with prickly carbonation. Lingering, piney hop finish.

22 oz. Bottle purchased at Spruce Street Provision. Color is a real deep ruby, borderline mahogany in color, very thin head. Aroma is huge pine hops caramel and crystal malts. 
Flavor is a nice hoppy rendition of a amber ale. Toffee, bready malt and caramel malts. Body is medium with a dry pine finish. Pine forward amber ale that drinks pretty much as it should be.
Bomber shared by AirForceHops. Thanks, Chris! Bottled 12/1/15. Pours dark red brown (not amber) with a beige head. Aroma is big pine. Reminds me of Weez. Flavor is multigrain bread, honey, pine.

Aroma: caramel, toast, floral, citrus, pine
Appearance: dark amber with a tan head
Taste: medium sweetness, medium bitterness, 
Palate: medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish, 

Tasty

Bottle, pours a beautiful dark mahogany with a thick, lasting beige head. The aroma pops nicely on this one - a great medley of citrusy/piney PacNW hops, fresh bread, toasted malts and burnt orange. Flavor has a real great balance of the flavors mentioned in the aroma along with the perfect level of sweetness and bitterness. Toffee and grapefruit aftertaste with a tinge of wood. Body is medium with a smooth texture and fine carbonation - would have preferred a little more body on this one, though. Overall great stuff. Reminds me a bit of Bear Republic Red Rocket back in the day.
Pours clear brown. Aroma is citrus, floral, earl grey, mild coffee. Medium-low bitterness. Very well balanced.
Really full flavors of chocolate, cocoa, coffee and caramel. Slightly bitter, with roasted notes on the front of the palate and a gentle sweet finish. Balanced and rich.
Tap at whole foods, columbus circle. Dark reddish color, tanned head. Aroma has fruity notes, hops, some berries. Nice crispy taste, some berry notes, hops.

Growler filled from The Hop Yard, Raleigh. Pours deep reddish brown burgundy with a nice tan head that fades to a very leggy rim. Aroma is sweet caramel malt. Taste is very malty with a hop-bitter aftertaste. Nutty, dry caramel malt backbone with a bit of toffee and mild citrus malt. Malt-heady but nicely balanced. Excellent.

Bottle to glass. Pours a deep amber mahogany color with a tan head. Aroma is malty, with a hint of piney hops. Flavor is pure amber malts without much hop character. Decent amber, just expected a bit more hops coming from AleSmith.
Draft. Pours amber with a beige head. Balanced, with mild sweet malts, some fruity and pithy hoppy bitterness, and a balanced finish. Fine.

22 oz. bottle from The Hop Yard, Raleigh (bottled December 1, 2015). Reddish-orange pour with a frothy khaki head. Aroma of tangerine, light cherry, faint chocolate, and sweet caramel. Taste is good with well-balanced hop bitterness and malt. Perhaps this is just a bit too balanced to make it great in my book but it¬ís a well done amber ale all the same.
650ml bottle. Dark amber pour aroma is citrus candy ad bread. Flavor is caramel, toast, hops, resinious, dnak. Woudl be more appropriate for a 6 pack, as a bomber beer it is worthless.
Deep amber colour with a fairly persistent head. Taste is a little disappointing, but it¬ís not bad overall. Based on reviews for Evil Dead Red I had expected more, but it¬ís still decent.

Lukt: Citrus og karamell.
Utseende: M√∏rk kastanje farge.
Skum/kullsyre: Lite skum.
Smak: Citrus og karamell.
Hvor: Nydt@√òlsmaking hos Bryne med Geir og Untapped Erik.

An elaboration of Evil Dead, with thick and frothy, dense, pale beige, thickly lacing head and deep hazy burgundy red colour. Strong and appealing aroma of blood orange, dried grapefruit peel, ¬íhaemoglobin¬í iron, walnuts, hazelnut oil, pink pepper, dried leaves, toasted brown bread, dried banana. Dried fruits in the onset, soft sour berry and passion fruit accent, some dry banana, medium carbo, very nutty maltiness with bitter toasted aftertaste nicely paired with a long, spicy, citrusy, drying hop bitterness, a tad piney and dry citrus peel-like retronasally. Another delicious and appetizing AleSmith.

from kihoskh,, clody brown, smooth offwhite to light brown head.

nice malty, hoppy , nutty aroma, slightly spicy, but still tasty bone dry us hoppy. Flavor is malty, herbal, lots of sweeter us hops, but loads of bitter hops too, ends up being a malt and hop forward thick full flavor beer which is an absolute joy to drink.

Tasted bit too warm, but anyways very nice. Intense maltiness, toast, caramel, some cocoa in background, light fruity, dried fruits notes. Moderate sweet with light bitterness. Well balanced and lovely brew
Tasty, like classy American amber/red but with addition of toasted malts. Very caramely aroma, sweet and hoppy. Above medium body.

Brown/red clear with medium beige head. Roasted malt and herbal aroma. Medium bitterness mixed with sweet roasted malt and bread taste, herbal notes. Bread and herbal aftertaste with lasting bitterness.

Fonefan 110415. Red dark brown colour with a beige head. Aroma is malt, toffee, bread, pine, orange. Flavour is alcohol, malt, hop, toffee, bread, pine, orange, citrus, caramel, chocolate, floral. Very nice beer.

650ml bottle from Firmabier


Deep red colour with a small head. Hoppy, tasty, malty. Good.

Very dark red with a beige head. Aroma is malty caramel, floral and fruity hop, toast. Full bodied and rather smooth. Flavor follows the aroma with a bit of chocolate malt. Real nice balance of malt and hop in this amber. Meaty and delicious.
Bottle. Ruby with a tan head. Piney resinous aroma, dried fruit, raisins and prune. Taste is similar, pine, grapefruit, dried fruit, stewed fruit. Slightly bitter. Nice.
bottle at home ... dark brown ... small tan head .. soft toffee .. soft sweet fruits .. soft toffee malts ... soft toffee caramel fruit.. soft sweet toffee fruit
Bottle at Craigs. Pours clear chestnut with a head. Aromas of resin, wood spice, caramel. Taste is caramel, nutty, wood spice. Sticky finish.
Bottle at craig¬ís. Pours deep ruby, nose is burnt toffee, malty, taste is dry, bitter, toffee, light fruit.

650ml bottle. Clear, ruby red colour with average to huge, thick, creamy, fairly lasting, moderately lacing, beige head. Piney, slightly resinous hoppy aroma and... yes, that¬ís it, piney hoppy aroma - maybe a nuttily touch. Taste is piney hoppy, minimally resinous, notes of candied orange zest, slightly nuttily undertones; smooth, soft, silky palate. Simple and straight to the point - naturally with the well known, inspiring Alesmith cleanliness.
Bottle @campingratebeer¬í15. Brown color with no head. Smells and tastes malty, hoppy, fruity.
Sampled @ Camping Ratebeers 2015. Superb dark red color, medium sized off-white to beige head. Smell and taste malts, sweetish, dark fruits, slightly alcohol. Medium body and carbonation. Quite nice.

Bottle at home, shared (bottled on 12/1?/14). Pours a, light hazy, dark ruby red with an off-white to pink head. Aroma of piney hops, caramel, bready malty, dark fruits, hint of coffee and chocolate. Taste is light to medium sweet, hoppy bitter, malts, caramel, coffee, hint of chocolate, bitter dry ending, lots of coffee, a hint of chocolate and more hoppy bitterness in the aftertaste. Nice.
Light brown colour with good head retention. Strong hoppy aroma, quite earthy and piney. There¬ís some caramel sweetness in the flavour to balance the strong hop flavour.

Fruits and berries in the aroma. The taste is bitter and fruity. Heavy bitterness that fills the mouth forever. Good but too bitter for me to like it. Follow me @ Kung av √∂l @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.

February 17th, 2013 - I love a beer that has an unidentifiable style. It grapples with boundaries, pushing them and warping them, much to the benefit of the drinker. Under this category of outr√© brews is Alesmith¬ís My Bloody Valentine - a departure from my favorite beers there which are decidedly dark and boozy. The smell is spicy, with lots of grape juice and grape Kool-Aid, old and dusty wood, clove, and a little juniper, with some brown sugar too. The flavor thunders with a heavier booziness than the smell portends. Caramel and dark sugars greet the tongue, heavy and callous, almost like a large, blundering stout. Add in raisin and fig, blackberry and a nice juniper dryness and you have a nice, dark mix of sweeter high notes and sluggish low notes, and a constant line of hops bitterness all the way through.

Pour is more mahogany-brown than mahogany-red. But coupled with a lasting tan-head it¬ís a delight in the glass. Aroma is fairly sweet and enticing. At this point in its life (3 months old) the aroma is caramel-malt driven. Also some pine, spice and a hint of berry-hop presence.

Interesting. Good aroma. Good mouth feel. Delicious. Had high hopes after seeing it was ranked among the best ambers and my expectations were met. Definitely worth a try for any amber fans.

Reddish brown with a big tan head. Aroma is roasty malt. Flavor at first is spicy hops, and then malty sweetness follows, some chocolate and candied orange. Excellent beer, even if I¬ím not a big fan of the style.

Bomber - typical hoppy American red ale, but a decently constructed one, I suppose - malts are toasty and sweet (caramel, pumpernickel, some raisin) - some acidity through the middle braces for the earthy, woody hops and bitterness that follows - finish is a little watery - it¬ís good for what it is, but I can walk into plenty of brewpubs across the country and get pretty much the same beer.
a nice blend of malt and hops. a well made beer but nothing special. it would be a nice winter drinker but not worth the price of a bomber.

From a 22 oz bottle shared at home on Easter Sunday. Pours a clear dark amber with an ecru head. Crisp mildly hoppy nose, Flavors of blood oranges and some pine resin. Medium bodied. Moderate carbonation. Clean finish.

Bomber poured into tulip. This one didn¬ít start too well because the cap was so tight that when it finally popped open the bottle slipped and almost fell on the ground...and started gushing. Oh well. That incident aside, let¬ís now move on...! Pours a nice uhm, well, bloody brown/red with a substantial head which leaves heavy lacing on the glass. Aroma is of dried prunes, tangled with grassy hops and a strong caramel/toffee malt backbone. There¬ís also some strange, but ok subdued citrusy aromas in the background. I do have to say that the bottle was picked up last August, so that beer must have been brewed around December 2012...some aromas ought to have evolved. Taste is rather sugary, with the herbal hoppy bitterness balancing it off nicely. Mouthfeel is really nice; it has this slick texture that is usually found in higher abv brews. Carbo is a bit over average. Aftertaste is medium bitter, with a bit of acidity, which might be due to the ale¬ís age. Overall, a pretty good red ale. I would not say memorable, but still really nicely built.
Bottle thanks to my sister in San Diego. Pours brownish red with a tan head. Nose is caramel and dried fruit. Very hoppy.

Bottle, thanks Ryan, as you drain pour it? Red brown pour with tan head. Some reminisce of hop aromas, with a stronger malt backbone. Flavor has some spice and earthy tones but most of the hop richness has faded. Hoping this is last years bottle....

22 ounce bottle into tulip glass, bottled on 12/24/2013. Pours fairly crystal clear dark red color with a 2 finger dense khaki head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that lingers. Spotty foamy lacing clings on the glass. Aromas of big grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pineapple, citrus rind, caramel, toast, toffee, floral, grass, light pine, and floral/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good complexity of citrus hops with moderate malt balance; and good strength. Taste of grapefruit, tangerine, lemon zest, orange peel, pineapple, citrus rind, caramel, toast, toffee, floral, grass, light pine, and floral/toasted earthiness. Light amount of floral/pine bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of grapefruit, tangerine, orange/lemon zest, pineapple, citrus rind, caramel, toast, toffee, and floral/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Damn nice complexity of bright citrus/floral hops with moderate caramel/toast malt sweetness; with a great malt/hop balance and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Medium carbonation and body; with smooth, crisp, and lightly creamy/sticky mouthfeel that is nice. Alcohol is very well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an excellent amber ale. All around great balance and complexity of citrus/floral hop and dark/toasted malt flavors; and very smooth to drink. A very enjoyable offering.
I wasn¬ít a huge fan of this beer. i love alesmith but this one was not for me.

Bottle: Thanks, Kevin! Dark copper-ish, brown-ish body with a gray & beige tinted, fading head that quickly transcends to a chunky, lasting collar. Aroma is full of lightly dank, weedy hops, somewhat floral grassy with a malty, caramel-like underbite from the malt, creating an all around bittersweet nose. HMOG 2014. Superb hoppy amber. Big citrus and floral hops, but there is still the known malty amber base in the background. I was actually quite proud of myself after 35 pours to make this distinction verbally to jrob21. Good stuff.

Pours a clear ruby red with a pale, slightly pinkish buff head. Malty, hoppy and slightly - is that strawberry? - aroma invites a taste. Hoppy flavor is almost like an IPA, but fairly malty and with a sweet and slightly tart strawberry underpinning. Smooth mouthfeel is fairly tingly.

Deep orange brown. Heavy lacing. Some caramel malts on the nose giving way to earth hops as it warms. Similar experience with the taste...very malt forward at first with a lot of caramel, almost like an old-ale-lite, then becomes more of like a hoppy amber. Solid.
Brown with a khaki head. Hops, pine, fresh, sticky, and malts. Great chewy palate, piney hops, bread, dough, great finish.

Bomber from Rays in Tosa. Pours an orangey brown with an orange head leaving some nice lacing. Aroma has sweet fruits, stone fruits, pine, tangy spices and caramel. It has been a while since I visited an Alesmith rate. This looked like a good one given the time of year. A fine amber ale made the January snow melt away. If it comes around again in 2014 I would certainly pick it up or order a pint as a starter at the tasting room.

Aroma / Appearance - A ruby semitransparent base is trapped under an ivory ring of head. Musty cedar, almonds, and dry chocolate permeate the air with a soft feel. More malt driven than many West Coast amber ales it strikes a nice balance.

Flavor / Palate - Malt balls dipped in dry semisweet chocolate fill the mouth with a pleasant texture. Warming the palate after a few sips, it betrays that this is not a mild mannered sessionable amber ale. Sticking in the throat with a dry bitterness the outcome is a very well rounded release that shows all the hallmarks of a beer well worth the $8.99 price tag. If you see this on the shelves and want a change of pace from hop bombs or big imperial styles this fits the bill.

The sweetness in the nose is contrasted by a more dry malt flavour. Extremely well-balanced with high drinkability. Another most excellent AleSmith creation.
Bottle pours a deep red with a tan top. Scent is caramel, floral and citrus. Taste is caramel, bread, citrus a a bit of chocolate.

Bottle shared with Keith. Poured a hazy amber with massive off white head, tiny bubbles good lace. Aromas and taste of caramel, candy sugar, hops, vanilla, plum and bitter pine. Finishes with a pretty big bite. Enjoyable but i prefer any ipa or pale over an amber.

Looks and smells amazing, solid pour, frothy head, sweet smelling.

Taste is also good, imperial red ale, deep malty taste backed up by a solid hop punch.  Has a fruity sweetness to it, and almost like a cask flavor element as well.  Complex and very drinkable.

Nice!

22oz bottle in a tumbler.  Pours ruby/brownish with a lacy, light beige head.  Aroma of a lot of caramel and toffee in the malts plus a good amount of citrusy hops.  Flavor the same, with a very nice blend of hops and malts.  Average texture.  Another awesome Alesmith beer.

Acquired in a trade. Enjoyed at fridge temperature in a tulip

A - Murky reddish brown, nice stout-like 3 finger tan head formed and reduced to half a finger pretty fast.

S - Very hop forward and dry hopped on the nose. chinook and simcoe and centennial. Lots of grapefruit and pine needles.

T - Nice up front clean and bright bitterness followed by an english malt backbone but finishes with a thump like stale water from a week old thermos. Sort of a candied sugar taste as it lingers around.

M - Almost a heavy body and drinks like a 9%+ ABV beer. 

O - I love the nose and up front taste this beer delivers but it¬ís a thud of a finish.

22 ounce bottle.  Served in a nonic pint glass, the beer pours reddish/amber (more of a bright red when held up to a light) with an inch and a half light tan head that stayed around for a while.  There¬ís a good amount of lacing.  Aroma is nice and hoppy, the brew smells like floral and citrusy (grapefruit, oranges) hops, caramel malt, and some mint.  It tastes like citrusy and pine hops, caramel, toasted malt, toffee and a bit of chocolate.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, it¬ís a bit slick with a good amount of carbonation.  I liked this brew, it¬ís definitely worth a try.  $8.99 a bottle.

ours a dark reddish amber with a nice three finger off white head with a ton of lacing.  Aroma is very nice and is of pine resin, citrus, floral hops toasted malts, caramel, toffee, brown sugar, and some nuts.  Taste is of pine, citrus, sweet  toasted malts, caramel, and some brown sugar.  Has a medium body with a smooth, semi creamy mouthfeel and a semi bitter, slightly warming, well balanced finish.  overall,  tasty and well balanced amber ale that is now my new favorite for the style.

Clear, deep reddish brown, excellent creamy foam top and lacing on the glass. Resinous hop aroma with a touch of dankness. Some fresh grain. Bitter flavor, resinous again, not much else going on. Not bad but it is one dimensional.

Bottled. Mahogany in color with a large frothy beige head. Excellent retention and lacing. Flawless appearance. Bright aroma of spicy, sprucey hops, caramel malt and soy. Light-med sweet flavor with a subtle bitterness. Good malt core. Medium body, thick texture and a fruity, light bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours beautiful clear deep red-amber with a small off-white creamy head that dissipates slowly with nice lacing. Aroma is floral, citrus, caramel, a touch of spice. Flavor is the same, light sweet and light to medium bitter. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, bubbly carbonation.

Bottle...  Poured deep, rusty red with a moderate, khaki head.  Nose had nice citrus and pine hop characters.  Quite green and fresh with hop notes.  Bready, malt sweetness for balance.  Rich and full bodied.  Both malt and hop complexity without being too bitter, sweet, or unbalanced in any direction.  Some dark fruity tones from yeast esters and a toasted, caramel sweetness in the finish.  Quite nice.

On tap at City Beer in San Francisco, served in a lager glass. Pours cloudy mahogany with a small tan head that remains. The nose has a big California Cascade hop aroma with caramel, roasted malts and earth. The flavour is balanced between medium malty sweetness and Cascade hoppiness with perhaps a touch of rye. The finish is long and balanced with hoppy notes from the nose. On the palate, it is medium in body with a dryish texture and average carbonation. Overall, this is a very nice red ale with a beautiful hoppy nose. Very tasty. 2012-02-17
Red auburn pour Creamy eggy head. Mellow toasty red. Light body. sweet caramel malts bury floral hops. Slightly bitter finish. Excellent easy drinking for the style.

Tap at PPCB. It pours cloudy, very dark red, with a thin beige head. The nose is leaf, grass, cherry, plum, pine and caramel. The taste is pine, resin, leaf, grass, caramel and some dark fruit (plum and raisin), with a dry, slightly warming finish. Alcohol is well hidden. Medium body and low/soft carbonation. Very easy drinking.

Sampled on tap at Beer Revolution on 2/14/2012. This amber ale pours a slightly hazy medium brown color from the tap. Medium sized white foamy head. The aroma is caramel, fruity, hoppy and sweet. A medium bodied amber. The malts are caramel, fruity and sweet. The hops are grapefruity and earthy, Medium carbonation. I am a little disappointed with this beer. The malts are hops in this beer are a mess, they are not mixing well at all. Wonder if it was a bad keg, I don¬ít think it was a bad tap line but there is something way off with this beer. Mouthfeel is full. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.
Draft. Rich amber beer with a tan head. Grapefruit and malt aroma. Grapefruit and light pine flavor with caramel. Medium bodied. Caramel and grapefruit lingers.

On tap at City Beer. Pours dark reddish brown with a decent beige head and a cherry and treacle aroma. There isa bitter dark malt flavor with lots of hopping. This is a very strange and unique earthy brew. I started off not liking it, but half-way throught the glass it started tasting better.

Tap at Pizza Port San Clemente. Pours a very deep ruby to deep cola (more like a brown ale to lighter porter) with really no head formation. Nose is thicker toffee, red fruits, strawberry milkshake, heavier dessert character. Taste is thicker, salty, fairly sticky, lots of toffee piling on. Stinging carbonation on the palate. A bit heavier in mouthfeel for style.
draft at Beer Revolution- Murky brown body. Slight tan head. Aroma wafting up from glass slight of hops. Kind of watery. Some slightly grainy backbone. Underwhelmed.

On draft at Tustin Brewing Company.  I have no idea if this was an old keg or what as I don¬ít see any current ratings.  Pours a deep red with slight head that is very visually appealing based on the name and the fact that we are three days from Valentine¬ís Day.  That¬ís the extent of the positives.  The aroma is slightly earthy with minimal hop character.  Taste, dirt.  This was just bad with the malt being there on second taste but just more earth coming through in a stale and bland fashion.  Overall this was a beer that I can¬ít imagine was supposed to taste like this based on the other reviews.  Not sure if this was "cellared" for a few years or what but I¬íd be more than hesitant to order this one again.
user_location: Morro Bay via Orange County, California, USA

text: Cask at the PB Taproom.   Dark red/brown color with a beige head. Fruity and floral hop aroma with lots of caramel and chocolate malt mixing in. Hops are more soft and fruity in the flavor and bitterness is pretty restrained. Big, deep malt flavor with dark fruit, caramel, and chocolate. Silky mouthfeel and medium body. More balanced toward malt than I had anticipated, but still some nice floral and fruity hop character.
A top flight Amber Ale from Alesmith, loaded with pineapples, grapefruits, and sticky malt goodness. Ballin.
From the tap poured a dark amber color with a fair amount of head.  Nice sweet toasted malty flavor with a quick finish.

Poured a reddish amber with strong malts and a little hop on the nose.  Taste is sweet and malty with some hop in the back.  I also picked up a cantaloupe flavor which was nice.  It is a clean and fresh beer very enjoyable.
A decent offering, well worth the money and i¬íd possibly get it again. Just didn¬ít knock my socks off. hop profile was not up to snuff. greatly prefer their evil dead red.
Amber brown pour with a small head. Aroma has some hops, sweetness and a touch of cocoa. Flavor is sweet, balanced, some hops, brown sugar and chocolate. Yum.
Brown pour with white watery head and lace. Resiny hops with light malt aroma. Medium malt (caramel) medium/large citrus bitter. Medium bodied with a hint of water.

growler thanks to Deadgirl!  Pours brown with a tall off white head.  Aroma is strong hop and a caramel note as well.  Flavor is rich biscuit and caramel malt with a nice crisp and clean fruity hop finish.  I agree this is almost like an IPA, but the malt character is slightly more complex.  Alesmith rocks!

Tap, Blue Palms.  Short: a deliciously fresh, hoppy amber.  Color is dark blood red.  Aroma is spicy and floral.  Flavor balances the crisp hop notes with mild caramel and acidic red fruit (blood orange anyone??  Finishes with a quick flourish of bitterness.

Growler, clearly the BEST amber ale i¬íve ever had!!!   Pours an amber body with an off white head.  Really fresh and hoppy nice pine, citrus, and tangerines.  Really tropical, sweet and fruity with a piney and lush grassy finish.  Well i¬ím positive why this is my favorite amber b/c it definitely blurs the line of an ipa, i could drink this shit all day and night beautiful, thanks to Dak for the share.

Tap at Blue Palms.  AHazy red with a one finger beige head, creamy and coating with fair retention.  Lots of tasty citrus and pine hops, even a bit spicy, followed by a sweet toffee and lightly earthy caramel malt backbone.  Flavor is much the same with bitterness fairly tame at first, but quickly builds as being very piney and earthy.  Lots of toffee and citrus rinds going on as well.  Some toasty malts hang in the background with the slightest tinge of roasted malt.  Finishes semi-dry with bitterness at a 4, though seemingly well balanced.  Medium smooth body with light to moderate carbonation.  Breaks the mold for the otherwise boring amber style, and is more like an imperial red lite.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Date: March 13, 2010
Mode: Growler
Source: Tasting, RBWG 2010
Appearance: hazy amber, fine beige head, drippy lace
Aroma: sweet citrus aroma, caramel sweetness, lots of hops
Flavor: sweet malt flavor, lots of citrus and earthy hops, long bitter finish
Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 15/20
Rating: 3.6/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: *** /4

Aroma is resin hops, some medium malt.  Taste is resin/citrus hops bite, some medium malt-a bit of licorice/peat.

RBWG, thanks to smokepot23 for sending this for me to share.  Red pour.  Citrus and spicy hops combine with a nice aroma of caramel malt.  Flavor is hoppy and loaded with caramel.  Well done for a usually boring style.  Alesmith rocks.

Thanks to Dak for sharing this growler at RBWG. Pours a reddish amber. Nose is super hoppy, at first I thought this was an IPA. Citrus, light grain and some grassiness. Intense hop flavor up front and a chewy malt body that really holds up well with a rather long bitter finish. Not my thing but this is really well done.

A: The pour is deep amber color with a lot of brown to it. The head is minimal at a little less than a finger¬ís worth of off-white foam.

S: The nose is almost exactly what I look for in a red ale. Plenty of grapefruit and miscellaneous citrus notes from the hops with a nice toasty and bready malt backbone and a mild pine quality.

T: Fairly similar to the taste with a hit of citrus on the front end, sweet bready and caramel malt in the middle and a bit of bitter pine on the finish. Not quite as good as the aroma, but still quite nice.

M: The body is medium with a moderate level of carbonation and a crisp finish.

D: One of my new favorite beers from Alesmith. It¬ís unfortunate that this beer isn¬ít one of their "staples", but I suppose it will make me look forward to the opportunities I get to have it.

Hazy brown pour (which I didn¬ít expect cause of the name) with a creamy tan head ... lacing ... smell of light piney hop .... sweet malty caramel taste with dark fruits and a hoppy citrus bite .... its thinner than it looks and is very sessionable .... a very good beer

Kinda of a dark brown with a strong hint of red mixed in. Malty aroma with pine and a bit of citrus hops. Very pleasing taste, nice and solid with a hoppy flavored ending that doesn¬ít really add much bitterness. I expected this to be ok, but ti really turned out to be much nicer than I expected.

On tap at Pizza Port (Solana Beach, CA): Poured dark brown with some red highlights if held up to the light. Needless to say I was disappointed with the appearance as my expectations were a lot higher for such a cool name. However, the aroma and taste certainly makes up for it. Very hoppy for an amber. Aroma of citrus and pine perfectly balanced with some dark malts. Flavor is similar- fresh clean pine and citrus hops balancing with a smooth but not cloying maltiness. Delicate hop finish. Drinkability: Simply delicious. Pairing: Wide range of food; chicken, seafood, burgers, and spicy cuisine. I paired it with the Solana Beach pizza served at Pizza Port. Rebuy: Certainly. #287 on 25022010, DG.

From tap at Pizza Port San Clemente. Pours hazy to murky brown with a small tan head. Aroma is mild fruity and dark breadish malty. Dark breadish and toffee malt flavoured with a light fruity note showing through. Dark malty and fruity finish with a light bitterness.

Draft @ Father¬ís Office (Santa Monica). Pours a hazy, dark amber-brown color; creamy light-tan head with excellent lacing. Good amounts of basic fruitiness, toffee, and pleasant earthy bitterness; balanced, moderately dry, pleasant. Medium-to-full body; creamy presence, lively carbonation; pleasantly earthy and citrus bitterness, toffee, nuttiness, and slightly oily malt character; a nicely bitter amber; some sweetness and malty heft at the core; lasting finish of caramel, red fruits, earthy bitterness.
On Cask at SD Tap Room. Excellent head retention. Dark amber in color. Very hoppy aroma taste and flavor. Hints of caramel malts as well.  Another great one from AleSmith
CASK, they tapped the bung the same day I was drinking this, big frothy tan head, red amber coloring, aroma is some columbus and amarillo, flavor is columbus, body is thin and firkin-ish. Good stuff!

Unexpectedly hoppy.  I was expecting a Valentine beer to have a fruity sweetness to it, but it was balanced out quite nicely by some aggressive hopping.  Dark ruby red color with a thick foamy head.  Interesting beer.
100th rating: Pours murky brown, aroma of hops, chocolate and malt. Medium to low carbonation with amazing mouthfeel. Sweet chocolate with nice balancing bitterness.
Poured a brown/reddish color with small head. Aroma was caramel and sweet hops. Taste was similar with a malt backbone. Overall it was good but I like Evil Dead Red more.

Taster at alesmith.  Pours a dark red amber with a thin tan head.  Aroma is lots of pine and some citrus.  Flqvor is moderately bitter with lots of citrus and pine and slight malt, less than expected.  Palate is medium with moderate carbonation.

Growler fill from brewery.  The first pour from the growler reveals a the color of a dark plum (dark red, almost black/brown) with almost three fingers of beige head with good retention.  Aroma is much more hoppy than you would expect considering this is categorized as an amber.  Grass, pine, and citrus tones abound in the nose along with a hint of caramel.  Flavor also initially has quite a hoppy presence but a balancing maltiness soon emerges.  An earthy hoppiness again makes an appearance in the finish.  This has a surprisingly light mouthfeel which I¬ím not crazy about, but otherwise another great one from the fine folks at Alesmith.
Growler, courtesy of Beerlando.  Pour a dark red with an equally hoppy and malty aroma.  Flavors are strong on the hops, citrus and some toffee.

A- Pours a deep red hue with an ample amount of tan head.

S- Smells hoppy for an amber, with deep bready notes.

T- Taste is very full. Bready with notes of caramel and toffee and rounded out with good floral hop accents and a bit of bitterness.

M- Medium viscosity, perfect amount of carbonation.

D- Incredibly drinkable. I could drink this stuff all day. I loved the distinct hop presence in this one which was just enough to appease me without being so strong as to mask the complex maltiness.

This poured a ruby red color with a somewhat small off white head. Aroma on this was just phenominal, it smells like citrus trees and pine trees growing in the same forest, yum. Flavor was just as appealing, very fresh clean piner and citrus hops balancing out a very smooth but not cloying maltiness. This is very underated beer.

Sample from a growler.  Clear reddish amber color with a big tan head.  Lots of hop in the aroma, making it citrusy and piney with a bit of malt balance.  Citrus hop flavor, some other fruit in there, malt and a bitter finish.  Very nicely done.

Thanks to Homerwantsbeer for sharing a growler. This brew is a mostly clear dark reddish-brown color with a thin off-white head that diminishes steadily. Rings of lacing on the glass. The aroma is hoppy for an Amber, with notes of sweet malt and nuts in the background. Medium-bodied with a flavor pretty much how I would expect a hopped-up Amber from Alesmith to taste. Flavors of piney hops, caramel malt, fruit and nuts are all there. The finish is equally hoppy and malty with a lingering bitterness. My kind of session beer overall.
Courtesy hopscotch.  Clear mahogany color, broken white head.  Moderate candied NW hop aroma, although the malt base is apparent.  Mild taste, more balanced than the aroma, very drinkable.

UPDATED: APR 2, 2010 On tap at AleSmith. Great red-brown color.  Nose is sweetness of caramel and malt with nuts and hops.  Taste i sweet and malty.  Light and clear with the finish. March 27 update.  Moving up from 3.6  Seriously good mix of sweet malty and sharp hoppy.  Great drinking beer.

On tap at Hamiltons Tavern. Amber red with whitish head. Medium body. Aromas of slight citrus and malt. Good solid caramel malt sweteness with some moderate hop presence. Nice finish somewhat dry and bitter. Good bitter for an afternoon refreshment.

On tap at the BA Decadence release. Pours with a hazy brown body and a light brown head. Aroma is awesome with hops (great profile, but hard to pick out individual hops on this one), caramel and brown sugar. Taste is malty with brown sugar, caramel, toffee and a floral hoppy finish. Lively carbonation with a dry finish.

Excellent amber ale.  Very bitter, fresh hoppy aroma with some caramel malt.  Taste of pine, citrus, sweet fruit, caramel, nuts, and bitter hops.  Reddish amber pour with a sticky medium-large reddish light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Medium mouthfeel and fairly easy do drink for it¬ís complexity.  Well done!

From sampler at the brewery. A chestnut brown color with a small off-white head. The aroma is rich with very good caramel in the forefront, some nuts and hops also present. The taste is overtly nutty with almonds, walnuts and hazelnuts surrounded by mildly biter hops. The mouthfeel is medium in body. The finish is long with lingering dark fruits. Overall: A very well crafted amber ale.

Growler. Pours a deep dark reddish-brown with a thin off-white head. Aroma is sharp, with hops, pine, grass, herbs, and a hint of sweeter malt and fruits. Taste is a nice balance of bitter pine hops and sweet malt and dark fruits. Light lingering crisp bitterness. Very nice.

Served on tap at Pure Luck in Los Angeles. Pours dark red/brown with a thin head that leaves excellent lacing behind. Rich aroma of hops and pine. Smooth, malty body with notes of caramel and citrus. great, lasting hop finish. a very, very fine beer.

Huge thanks to wetherel for sending me a growler of this. Have wanted to try it for an entire year. Very nice beer. Pours a deep brown with red hues and just a pencil thin head. Looks like reddish iced tea. Aroma is mostly tea and malt, with just a touch of hops. However, the hops come through huge in the flavor. Wet dank hops with bitter hops on the back end. Nice carmel malts and a touch of candied sugar dance in and out with the hops. Just super, super hoppy. Very nice.

On tap @ Toronado: Rating is based off very short and brief notes. Nose is of west coast influenced hop. Dark red color with thin coating of head. Caramelized malt flavor with a ever presence of bitter hops. Somewhat empty than what I had expected more.
Sample from tap.  Amber color.  Nice and fresh and hoppy.  Easy to drink.  Nice session beer.
(on tap @ fathers office culver city)amber body with a light brown head.aroma of hops,and caramel malts.flavor is pine hops,chocolate,caramel malts,and fruits.best damn amber ale i have ever had.

Growler pour, thanks to Beelando for this gem. Bright cherry blood red pour with a thick white head. Big fragrant simcoe hop aroma, a little pine and citrus really nice. Thick and pungent. Smooth malt body, not too thick with a nice hop balance. This is an extremely drinkable beer for such a hoppy beer, the low abv makes this delicious.

From growler shared by Swolf3, thanks Steve! Some co2 left in there, slight hiss upon opening surprisingly since about a 3rd of the bottle had escaped, leaked, evaporated or whatever. Thin tan head that faded quickly, some spotty lace left behind. Slightly hazy amber red hued brew. Nice hoppy nose of pine and citrus, a little woodsy with some solid caramel malts too. Body is medium, a little flat on the palate, duh. Lightly oily and chewy. Well balanced flavors of malt and hops, piney, lightly grainy and bready with a bit of sweet caramel malts, orangey citrus notes also. Lasting hoppy malty finish kicked with a respectable hop bite. Been wanting to try this one for years, did not dissappoint! Must bo lovely, fresh off tap??!! Props to Alesmith and Swolf3 for sharing this one! Nice.

Growler shared by wolf, sent by hophead22. Thanks gentleman.... Poured a murkey red color, not much of a head. Nice hoppy aroma for a amber ale. Taste is hops, with a malt/barley backbone, and a little sweetness to it. Well balanced. Smooth and easy to drink. Overall, considering it was about a week old....solid beer.

Growler courtesy beerlando. Pours a dark crimson red color with a thick, foamy beige head that shows good retention. Sticky lacing is left behind as the head recedes. The aroma shows notes of big piney hops and citrus fruit over a sweet caramel malt base. THe flavors follow with the pine, citrus fruits, and floral hops all playing a role with their bitterness, but are balanced out nicely by the toasted caramel and cookie malts. Medium bodied and very smooth and easy drinking with a lingering bitter finish from the hops. This is one tasty amber ale. There is no doubt this one leads the way for this style. Another solid brew from Alesmith.

Growler thanks to Hophead22. Poured a "bloody" translucent red color with not much head.This Beer has a very strong hop aroma along with citrus, pine, and malt. Taste is very well balanced between hops and malt along with citrus, and pine, and a nice bitterness from the hops. Finished very smooth easy to drink and a very nice session beer. AleSmith doesn¬ít disappoint! It took a week to get here so I could just imagine how delicious this beer is right from the tap. Thanks again Tim for sending me this.

Growler.  True to its name, this pours a clear, dark, "bloody" crimson color.  A dense, foamy, cream colored head shows great retention and leaves thick, clumpy flares of ultra-sticky lacing behind.  The nose shows big pine resin hops and hints of citrus rind over a rich caramel and toasted biscuit malt, with faint hints of cocoa in the background.  Flavors are as pronounced as any amber you will ever find, yet astonishingly well balanced.  Substantial pine, citrus, and green floral hops add bitterness to counter the toasted caramel and cookie biscuit maltiness.  Medium bodied, smooth, and creamy up front, the finish lingers with dry, hoppy bitters.  This is a great, sessionable amber.  As with almost everything Alesmith makes, this hovers near the very top of the genre.

On tap at Hollingshead Deli in Orange, Calif. Big flavor and great complex texture. I really enjoyed this beer. Good hops with a hint of sweet caramel. I¬ím surprised it is only a 6.3% beer as I could feel it after only one beer which rarely happens.
Growler thanks to Beerlando.  Red like grenadine.  Malts were very present in the smell and very smooth in the taste.  Hops surprised me in the taste.  Really liked this,  could be enjoyed all day.

Growler¬Ö Clear crimson ale with a mid-sized, creamy, khaki head. Fantastic retention and thick lacework. The nose is chocolate and caramel malts intermingling with grapefruit, black tea, light pine and a suggestion of cat pee. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Well-balanced, with extremely high drinkability. Hints at cocoa and caramel with remarkably restrained pine and grapefruit essences.  Short, crisp, clean finish. Fantastic session ale. One of the best, if not the very best, amber ales I¬íve experienced. I could drink it all night¬Ö and live to tell about it. Huge thanks to Beerlando for skipping an Orlando Magic game in order to share this beauty with the Orlando Crew and we visitors from Vero Beach and West Palm Beach!

Growler courtesy beerlando.  Nice purple color. Piney resinous and also sweaty hop nose. Flavor leans more to chocolate malts, the flavoring hops are a bit soapy if anything. Nicely balanced finish, but the mouthfeel thins out some.

Draft. Pours a deep deep red with a nice lacing tan head. Sweet malty aroma, with a candy tone. Taste is very sweet malts, candy sugar. Reminds me of those cinnamon heart candies once the cinnamon starts to dissipate. Medium to full mouth with a sticky finish. Great amber ale, my favorite to date!!

Stunning beer.  Aroma is just perfect, great balance and texture.  subtle, and with good length.  tasted at alesmith and out of growler.  somewhat of a weird color but it doesn¬ít matter.  very easy to drink.  this beer is to rare.  should make more and bottle it.  also think this would make an AMAZING beer if it was barrel aged.  a little booze, oak vanilla char would set this off and be a 5.0 in my mind!
Tap at the brewery. Dark reddish pour. Nice dark malty aroma, very fragrent hop aroma. The flavor was more subdued on the hops, but very pleasent nonetheless. Very tasty brew.
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Draught at Alesmith.  Really wanted to try this beer and it did not disappoint. Very interesting amber ale.  More hops than expected at the start but then balanced out by heavily roasted malt in the finish.  Even some smoke in the end. Very unique.

Another one I have been wanting to try for a while.  Very dark auburn to reddish brown in color.  Aroma of reddish malt, lightly roasted malt, caramel, citrus and flowers.  Flavor was a bit more roasted than expected.  Some slightly sweet caramel with an earthy/woody finish.  Some fruit elements as well.  Good, but not as good as my expectations.

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2009 Tap at O¬íBrien¬ís, CASK at Linkery.  Looks as good as an Amber ever will.  Aroma is darker than expected and this is explained in the flavor, which is Malt Central.  I detected only a slight hop profile that tasted like Christmas Tree and didn¬ít do much to balance.  Has that bloody roundness of beef hearts, but not the flavor, just the full midpalate.  Much hoppier on cask.  Really odd beer for AleSmith.

Growler of MBV purchased at Alesmith, poured into a Sam Adams Specialty glass. 

Appearance is a clear deep ruby amber hue with a decent amount of thin white head, moderate lacing.

Smell is sweet caramel malts mingling with green piney hops, tones of peat and wood.

Taste is dominated by caramel malts, sweet sugary peat malt, some grassy and pine hops come up, hints of vanilla, orange/citrus, and some oak chips, finishes sweet and drying.

Mouthfeel is medium-bodied, thick and smooth texture, moderate carbonation.

Drinkability is moderate, this is a well-balanced amber with plenty of flavor, definitely a lighter cousin of Evil Dead Red and Decadence, this is more reminiscent of PP Sharkbite in terms of a lower hop presence, definitely worth trying in honor of V-day!

a darn good amber ale......lots of hops to balance the what would otherwise be way too sweet......great malt profile....and it almost seemed like a red ale....but it says here it is an amber so oh well?
Dark amber with a thin head. Light citrus aroma with caramel malt. Mild caramel malt sweetness, with toffee, toast, and a medium hoppy finish. Well done amber ale. A little different than most.

On tap at Pizza Port Carlsbad. Dark amber, malty citrus hoppy aroma. Full malt character, ranging from sweet caramel - dark crystal, hop profile hits nicely, finish is sweet and bitter just as I like it. A very nicely done American amber ale.
On tap at Liars Club.  Red copper with a fizzy white head.  Citrus hoppy aroma.  Caramel, lemon, molassess and a hoppy finish.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2009 On tap at OBriens with Katie. Re-rate after having a rather unappetizing cask version the year earlier. Beautiful clear bloody red-brown color with a copper hue that reflects the light nicely. Some head develops initially, slowly giving way to fine white lacing. Mouth-watering aroma of sappy hops and caramel malts. Well-rounded flavor profile that starts with lots of caramel and transitions directly to firm red ale bitterness. Crisp and clean finish. Medium bodied.
On tap @ Pizza Port Solana.  Pours a very dark amber with a medium sized off white head.  Hops played a bigger role than I thought they would.  Nice balance between malt and hops for the finish.

On tap at Pizza Port San Clemente
Dark red with a one finger off white head. Nice malt flavor with a touch of hops. For an amber ale, this has a nice amount of complexity and flavor. I¬íd like to see this around more often.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2007 Just like it¬ís sister beer - evil dead red.  On draft during February - hence name.  Nice copper red appearance with lots of lacing.  The nice smooth malt backgroud was the highlight.  Not packed with flavor - but overall a nice refreshing beer.   A nice subtle blend of caramel, sweets, and bittering hops.
draft at brewery.  monstrously balanced.  amber, but not at all malt-dominated.  pretty red beer anyways and quite hoppy.  extremely drinkable.  i¬íll throw in some toffee for good measure.

On tap at the brewery.  Big thumbs up to Peter and Ryan I believe at the brewpub for letting us in and trying some beer.  Pours a light pink red with an off-white head.  Very floral, fruity smell to it.  Hoppy as well.  Taste was very mellow, good subtle hop taste blended with a light malty sweetness to it.  It seemed to me everything about this beer was subtle which I think worked for it.  Finish was pretty smooth and a nice aftertaste was left behind.

On tap at the brewery.  Dark, ruddy amber pour with shades of gingerbread and a tall froth of off-white head.  Loads of fresh piney hops saturate the bouquet, with some edgy pink grapefruit thrown in to the mix for good measure.  A thorough cookie dough malty base backs it up, along with a bit of english toffee.  Medium bodied, well carbonated, yet soft mouthfeel; rich and full malty texture that has some residual sweetness left, but is more of a doughy treat than a sticky mess.  The flavors are much more malt oriented than the bouquet led me to believe, bringing out more toffee and cookie dough flavors.  A hint of caramel and toasted biscuit, but not to the realm of roasty by any means.  Clean finish with a gentle lingering hop bitterness making itself known in the final smack.

Sampled on tap at Alesmith Brewing, 2007 vintage.  Pours deep red with a substantial off-white head. Smells of caramel malts and piney hops.  Moderately sweet malt flavor with a light spice, hop bitterness is present.  Good finish, lingering sweetness.
deep red with a thick creamy head. Spicy carmel notes. Sweetish malty flavor, with a helathy noticable, but not overwhelming hops. A very enjoyable, well crafted beer.
Red caramel pour, rich in caramel malts with a noticable hop backbone. Full bodied, slightly fruity with some roasted malts, finishes with some nice spiceyness and sweetness.

Copper brown.  Small off-white head.  Aroma of rich caramel malts, slight toffee, pine, cinnamon, band-aid.  Flavor similar to aroma, with significant but not overwhelming hops.  Rich and flavorful.  Drinking it right now on tap at O¬íBriens in San Diego :)
Pours a deep amber hue with a light slight off-white head.  Aromas of caramel, a light pine.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied,flavors of caramel and hoppy, a light sweetness.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 Sampled last year at the brewery.  It is a decent red, malty and strong.  It isn¬ít the best I¬íve seen from Alesmith but its good.  I look forward to tasting the 2007 vintage this coming February.
Malty brew, with hints of fruits, slight hops, pretty well balanced, kind of a flavor of its own, decent brew.
(Draught, Stuffed Sandwich)  Pours a murky dark brownish red body with a medium-sized off-white head.  Aroma of light roastiness and spices.  Flavor of malt, mild hops, light fruit, and spices.

On tap pours slightly cloudy, deep red with a nice log lasting tan colored head. Aroma is mostly malt with a light hop nose. A nice complex beer with a lot of body and richness could have used a bit more bittering hops for me.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2014 2006 at O?Brien?s.  The beer pours to a dark brassy/brown body with a thin off-white head.  The aroma is light.  Toasty/roasty malts and supposed hops (I surely don?t smell the dry hopping).  The flavor is malty, toasted toffee, smooth yet very light hops.  Robust malts, tobacco.  The palate is a lingering tartness/bitterness in the back of the throat.  This is one of the weakest Alesmith products I?ve ever had, or I simply wasn?t in the mood to have it.  :( 3.2. Rerate on a 2014 bottle. This beer is just great.  Super easy drinking with a vibrant hop character that isn¬ít overly bitter. Pretty much the same description as before, but super nice hops sitting on a malty beer. I wonder if the keg wasn¬ít a little older when I first had this.

Deep crimson hughes i na dark body w/ a small tan lightly laced head.  Smells nicely dry hopped 1st big fresh citrus & grass then a nice sweet grain tone.  Average alate w/ some good carbonation.  flavor is like a dry hopped red ale sweet w/ toasted grains.  A well done red but only good.

Draft at O¬íBriens: Dark ruby chocolate color, nose of citrusy fruity hops, a bit of raspberry and light roast. Nice blend of creamy hop and fruity flavors. Nice body and thick mouthfeel. Balanced. Yum!

This is a dark beer that tastes nothing like a dark beer.  I assume that the use of de-bittered black malt is used.  The beer appears black but when held up to the light red around the sides can be seen.  This beer tastes mostly like an IPA but has very subtle chocolale and fig notes that barely come through.  Good effort but could be more refined.

Growler from the brewery.  Pours dark brownish-red with ruby highlights when held to light and a large creamy tan head.  Aroma features sweet dark roasty malts, figs, coffee, hazelnuts, a little earth, herbal and floral hops.  Flavor is complex, but predominantly malty - roasty with dark fruits, bitter chocolate, coffee, peat and earth and a pronounced yet gentle floral hoppiness.  Medium body and smooth, velvety carbonation.  A nice beer and unusual in style and flavor.

Tap @ Papago

Good sweet fruit aroma. Dark red body with tan head. Had mainly a flavor of plumbs and some hop bitterness on the finish. Medium dry palate a good brew.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2006 Dark with a frothy head. very nice malt and hop interplay and a refreshingly complex change from your everyday beer.  I dug it.  Almost like the grand cru without a belgian-styled yeast and with a large dose of american hops.

Draft at San Diego Brewing Company.  Nice red color as expected.  Decent head that lasted for quite a while.  Very sweet aromas.  Fruity and hops.  Flavor was sweet maltiness and hoppy too.  Did I taste raspberry in there or did the color just make me think I did.  Pretty good stuff.

Draft.  Deep ruby red with a think light tan head.  Rather sweet malty aroma with some nutty tones.  Candy sweet malt flavors with caramel.  Ruddy huskiness/nutshell finish.  Mouthfeel is medium heavy, rather sticky.

Cask and draft @ the brewery!  Pours a deep yet clear, rich red color with a decent sized off-white head and decent amount of lacing.  Aroma is very smooth and full of caramel and slightly hoppy.  Flavor is very similar, very smooth mouthfeel and easy going down.  Hints of caramel through-out.  I actually enjoed this beer more on tap than on cask because I thought the flavors stood out more and complimented the beer better.  Yet another great beer by Alesmith!

Pours with a deep blood red body topped by a thick head with a good amount of lacing.  It¬ís sweet and malty with notes of caramel and a nice citrusy hop note that adds a great bitterness.  Medium bodied and smooth.  I had both the cask and the draft versions.  Both were great but the cask was a little young and seemed a little weaker in both aroma and flavor.
